    A & E Example Combine Example Logging Example Prescribing Example

    Combine Example

    combine.Rmd

    Peamble for nice formatting

    library(eider)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'eider'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     transform
    library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(tidyverse)
#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.5.0     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter()     masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::group_rows() masks kableExtra::group_rows()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()        masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
kbl <- function(x) {
  x <- head(x, 10)
  x %>%
    knitr::kable(format = "html",
                 table.attr = 'data-quarto-disable-processing="true"') %>%
    kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped",
                              full_width = FALSE)
}

    1. Read in data

    This time we will need 2 data sets, the A&E data and the Prescribing data

    ae_data_filepath <- eider_example("random_ae_data.csv")
prescribing_data_filepath <- eider_example("random_pis_data.csv")

    This is the A&E data

    read.csv(ae_data_filepath) %>% kbl()
    id time attendance_category diagnosis_1 diagnosis_2 diagnosis_3
    2 2016-08-16 1 104 103 102
    2 2015-07-28 1 101 103 104
    16 2017-09-20 1 102 101 104
    10 2016-03-25 1 104 103 101
    5 2016-09-20 1 103 104 101
    6 2016-02-11 1 103 102 101
    14 2016-02-14 1 102 103 104
    14 2015-11-09 1 104 103 102
    14 2016-03-24 1 102 101 104
    1 2015-07-01 1 103 104 101

    and this is the prescription data

    read.csv(prescribing_data_filepath) %>% kbl()
    id paid_date bnf_section num_items
    19 2017-12-15 106 3
    19 2016-08-11 103 5
    19 2015-07-07 103 1
    7 2017-03-14 106 1
    3 2015-08-07 105 1
    18 2016-05-07 103 3
    2 2016-09-29 104 4
    5 2015-12-01 102 3
    2 2017-01-11 105 1
    6 2017-11-04 105 4

    2. Read in the specification

    This is what the specification looks like

    basic_combine_spec_filepath <- eider_example(
  "spec_example_combine_linear.json"
)
writeLines(readLines(basic_combine_spec_filepath))
#> {
#>     "transformation_type": "COMBINE_LINEAR",
#>     "output_feature_name": "sum_of_feature_1_and_feature_2",
#>     "grouping_columns": ["id"],
#>     "feature_list": {
#>         "feature_1": {
#>             "weight": 1,
#>             "source_file": ["ae2"],
#>             "transformation_type": "COUNT",
#>             "absent_data_flag": 0,
#>             "primary_filter": {
#>                 "column": "attendance_category",
#>                 "type": "IN",
#>                 "value": [1]
#>             }
#>         },
#>         "feature_2": {
#>             "weight": 1,
#>             "source_file": ["prescribing"],
#>             "transformation_type": "COUNT",
#>             "absent_data_flag": 0,
#>             "primary_filter": {
#>                 "column": "bnf_section",
#>                 "type": "IN",
#>                 "value": [106]
#>             }
#>         }
#>     }
#> }

    3. Run the transformation 

    all_data_path <- list(ae2 = ae_data_filepath,
                      prescribing = prescribing_data_filepath)
# Note now there are two source files with aliases.

tf <- transform(all_data_path, basic_combine_spec_filepath)

tf
#>    id sum_of_feature_1_and_feature_2
#> 1   0                              9
#> 2   1                              5
#> 3   2                              5
#> 4   3                              4
#> 5   4                              2
#> 6   5                              4
#> 7   6                              7
#> 8   7                              7
#> 9   8                              6
#> 10  9                              5
#> 11 10                              5
#> 12 11                              3
#> 13 12                              6
#> 14 13                              9
#> 15 14                              6
#> 16 15                              5
#> 17 16                              3
#> 18 17                              8
#> 19 18                              3
#> 20 19                             10
